title: New York City Defies Feds, Lets Illegal Immigrant Gang Member Go Free
text:
New York City Defies Feds, Lets Illegal Immigrant Gang Member Go Free "... released back into the community ..." by Jack Davis February 22, 2017 at 10:52am Share on Facebook 420 Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
New York City has made it clear it will defy President Donald Trump’s efforts to end sanctuary cities, and to prove the point it allowed an illegal immigrant gang member from El Salvador to go free instead of complying with a federal order to hold him. 
“This man is by his own admission a member of a violent street gang and he was released back into the community,” said Thomas Decker, field office director for U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. “Honoring a detainer request is not about politics, it is about keeping New York citizens safe.” 
Estivan Rafael Marques Velasquez, a member of the notorious MS-13 gang, was released from Rikers Island on Thursday after serving time for disorderly conduct. Advertisement - story continues below Trump Set To Revoke Obama’s Order To Schools On Transgender Bathroom Access 
Mayor Bill de Blasio has said city officials will never collaborate with immigration officials. 
“We will not deport law-abiding New Yorkers. We will not tear families apart,” de Blasio said last month as he pledged not to “allow our police officers to be used as immigration agents.” 
In this case, a de Blasio spokeswoman said that despite allegations the illegal immigrant was a member of a gang, he had done nothing that under the city’s rules required him to be held. Advertisement – story continues below 
“The detainee was released after he pled guilty and served his time to an offense that does not qualify as a violent or serious felony under the city’s local laws‎, and his gang affiliation was not supported by evidence that meets even minimal constitutional standards,” City Hall spokeswoman Rosemary Boeglin said. 
“When ICE presents evidence to our city that an individual in our custody has been convicted of a violent or serious offense — one that threatens the public’s safety — we will fully cooperate,” she added. 
Velasquez, 19, has a criminal record that includes second-degree reckless endangerment, fourth-degree criminal possession of a weapon and disorderly conduct. Advertisement - story continues below
